scenes.location: SHARECROPPER SHACK ECU FINGERS LATE AFTERNOO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow a small boy's FINGERS on a strange contraption-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCRATCH, 10 years old, has a `DIDDLEY BOW', a piece of ba wire nailed to the side of the unpainted shack so it is stretched taut. He moves an old corn cob under it as a fr and makes TWANGY, pitch-shifting NOTES as he plucks the w His friend LONNIE stands moving his fingers over a BOARD has laid on the side of the porch floor. A few scrawny CHICKENS run around in the yard behind them-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave off with that, Scratch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aint bothering you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is.     That aint no kind of music. We see that the board has PIANO KEYS drawn across it and Lonnie is pretending to play a song on it-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Least I make a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah and it's a nasty one. Lonnie looks at the sky-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to try again tonight? Lonnie sits on the edge of the porch, gauging the time fr the setting sun-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLIDE GUITAR plays. A tuft of RAW COTTON bobs on the stem and we begin to scroll OPENING CREDITS-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We TILT and RACK to look over a FIELD OF COTTON, the boll plumped out and ready for picking, blowing in the breeze. A HARVEST HAND steps into the shot, looks toward the sett sun, wipes his face with a bandanna then stoops to pick t row in front of him. We PULL BACK to see other PICKERS, m and women in denim coveralls, old gingham dresses and har work shoes, wearing straw hats against the sun and traili LONG WHITE SACKS between their legs and behind them. The boys walk down between them in the opposite direction

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES.   We see the boys walking on a PATH thro the PINES-

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES. We float over RAILROAD TRACKS cutting through flat, piney woods, catching up the boys, who walk the ties-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES. The boys stroll past white buildings of ARMY BARRACKS. SOLDIERS, black and white, DRILL on the grounds-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river rolls past us in the FG as the boys cross a RAILROAD BRIDGE. We SUPERIMPOSE-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear PIANO MUSIC as we CRANE DOWN toward the HONEYDRIP LOUNGE, a ramshackle wooden roadhouse at a rural crossroa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE-colored light bulbs (a few broken) FLICK ON and OFF erratically around the HONEYDRIPPER SIGN as we TRACK towa and then THROUGH it on the way to the entrance, catching with Lonnie and Scratch. The boys step under the door-light, frantic with insects, go up on their toes to peek in through a window-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OVERHEAD ANGLE of long fingers on piano keys-

dialogues.speaker: SINGER
dialogues.text: A woman in her late 50's, early 60's, BERTHA MAE SPIVEY, leans into a MICROPHONE from where she sits on a stool on little makeshift stage, a glass of whiskey in hand, and S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a gal name of Betty Sue Shook it so much She got the German flu No matter how she done it No matter how she done it No matter how she done it She done it just the same As she sings we PAN and TRACK, moving through the large, empty COUNTRY ROADHOUSE-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You women don't worry About your life She made Jack the Ripper Throw away his knife- Only a few die-hard REGULARS are scattered at the tables bar stools. A pretty young woman in her late teens, CHINA DOLL, is behind the bar, head held in her hands, listenin aimlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter how she done it No matter how she done it No matter how she done it She done it just the same Lonnie and Scratch step in, cautiously looking around, ho that nobody will notice and tell them to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They plant themselves next to the piano, Lonnie intently watching the long fingers work the keys- we TILT to see TYRONE `Pinetop' Purvis, proprietor and piano player, in 50's. He acts as if the boys aren't there, concentrating the music. We SHIFT to include Bertha Mae as she wraps up the song-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A copper brought her in She didn't need no bail She shook it for the judge He threw the cop in jail No matter how she done it No matter how she done it No matter how she done it She done it just the same SLICK, a pretty, sharply-dressed man in his late 40's at bar, and MACEO, who sits at a table near the bandstand smiling throughout, APPLAUD. The sound makes the room see more empty. Ty stands, nods to METALMOUTH SIMS, a slight, worried-loo harmonica player who sits behind Bertha Mae-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take it for a while. As Ty crosses to the bar we hear RECORDED MUSIC booming f outside-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They makin all that racket again at Toussaint's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. And all them people over there buying drinks and throwing their money after them dice and whatnot. Lucky we got none a that here. Metalmouth launches into a HARMONICA INTRO. Ty pauses at counter next to Slick, who is attentively watching Bertha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can drink your liquor You can drink your cold can beer-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sounding good, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds fine.   Always has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can drink your good whiskey You can drink your cold can beer-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much of a crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a crowd at all. Just some stiffs who want to drink theirself to sleep without the music wakin em up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to advertise. Got an attraction like Bertha Mae-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can lay up with your sweet gal But Poppa don't you leave me here

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Singin is one thing, Slick. Whether people want to look at you while you do it is another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) You saying something about- Maceo arrives to join them, interrupting-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got quite a number over to Toussaint's place tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of young folks. Come to listen to that box of his. China Doll brings Ty a glass of whiskey.    He gives her smile-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, China Doll. We FOLLOW as Ty crosses to the door-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't see why we don't just turn our box on and let folks feed it nickels like they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lady is singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But didn't nobody come to listen to her, Slick. Ty looks out the door at-

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ACE OF SPADES CLUB
dialogues.text: -the RED-lit ACE OF SPADES CLUB across the road, PEOPLE hanging out in front, LAUGHTER heard from within-

dialogues.speaker: HONEYDRIPPER
dialogues.text: Ty reacts.    Behind him, Maceo indicates the near-empty

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the man say, you can't argue with failure. STOKELY, a bitter drunk who holds on to the end of the ba calls out to them-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why Slick here is like a preacher? Slick tenses, used to this-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause he does all his best work on his knees. Stokely almost chokes with laughter-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind him, he just a drunk-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear she put a ring through it and use it to yank him around the house. Slick starts to rise but Maceo puts a hand on his arm-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Tyrone don't allow no scufflin here, Slick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I oughta get me a old woman too, take care of the groceries. Just got to sweet-talk her some, give her a good poke now and then-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna drink, Stokely, or you gonna lay out back recoverin from that busted head you about to get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen- They all turn to see DELILAH, Ty's wife, coming out from back of the club. She is dressed for church-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doffs his hat)    Miss Delilah-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's behave ourselves. (sees) What are you boys doing in here? Out! Lonnie and Scratch, busted, hurry out.   Delilah turns he attention to China Doll-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what are you doing behind that bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's sixty seconds too long. Maceo, you get back there and take that child's place. China Doll mopes as she steps out from behind-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bring people their food. Don't you be messing with their liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cause nobody's here but these couple lost souls, haven't had an appetite since they give over to the devil. Maceo gets behind the counter as Delilah heads for Ty at door-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Pinetop's Honeydripper That's where I get my cold can beer At Pinetop's Honeydripper That's where I get my cold can beer- Maceo reluctantly moves down to take the order of NADINE, large, handsome woman with a prominent gold tooth who has just stepped in-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evenin, Maceo. You lookin good tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Likewise, Miss Nadine.   What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flirting) You know what you can do for me, sweet man. Maceo tries to slip the hook and be polite at the same ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like to drink?

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY
dialogues.text: Ty watches the CROWD in front of the Ace of Spades.   Del comes up to join him, indicates his drink-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many is that tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't dog me about that, baby.   Not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want China Doll behind that bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got to help out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not there she doesn't. You know she's not sposed to get excited-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much chance of that in here. (wistful) Harvest hands all been crowdin into Toussaint's place. The young ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get some of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stick their noses in here, get one little sniff of the music, and they gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking)   Maybe that's the wages of sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitter) Aint no sin happenin here tonight, baby, and there sure as hell aint no wages. Your God wants to chastise some sinners He best move on over to Toussaint's, got a whole barroom crowded with em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He isn't `my God'.   He's everybody's God. He looks at his wife-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How that tent meeting went tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viola Underwood found the Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought she found Him last year when they come through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Well, she must have lost Him again between then and now, cause she come down that aisle tonight hollering in tongues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Spirit didn't move you, though?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtful) Not yet.   Might be too late for me. Delilah surveys the room-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you're serving Alton Stokely.

dialogues.speaker: STOKELY
dialogues.text: Stokely has to use two hands to keeps his glass steady as drinks-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That poor man-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toussaint cut his credit off. Either he gets it here-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -or he drinks that paint-peeler Willie Pettigrew cooks up back in the swamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna drink himself to death in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Least he won't go blind first. Delilah shakes her head and heads out the door-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imonna go home and say a prayer for that man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after)   Say one for me too, baby.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: Bertha Mae is singing straight to Slick now, as Metalmout backs her up on the harmonica-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here sweet Poppa Let me whisper in your ear Come here sweet Poppa Let me whisper in your ear Go back to Alabama But don't you leave your Momma here Only Slick applauds-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was outstandin, baby.   You still got the voice. Bertha Mae, a little unsteady, holds onto Slick's arm as helps her off the stage-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sent a chill down my spine to hear you. Bertha Mae looks to Ty as he steps back in-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might be a little late Saturday, Tyrone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters, embarrassed) Don't need to come in if you don't want to. She stops dead.   Stares at him till he has to let it out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made other arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other arrangements-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try something new in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's his place, darlin, he can do whatever he want. Bertha Mae nods to Ty, holding onto her dignity for all i worth-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where to find me if you need me. Bertha Mae pulls Slick out the door. China Doll watches after them, troubled, while Ty pours himself another drin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)   I put the box on now, Ty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Put the box on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imonna crank it up some, see if we can draw a little life in here- Maceo crosses and plugs an ancient-looking tabletop JUKEB in. The jukebox sputters to life, LIGHTS FLASHING ON and MUSI BLARING for a moment, then the LIGHTS FLICKER and all the POWER in the club goes OFF!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Honeydripper SIGN is the last to FLICKER and DIE. Lonnie and Scratch watch from under the streetlight-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it go again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lectricity don't like that jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: China Doll? A MATCH is struck, FLARES as China Doll lights a KEROSENE LAMP she's pulled from under the bar-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to get the power company in here-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't. They turned my juice off last month- don't want them sniffin around that splice job Maceo done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a short circuit in the juke here- He yanks the plug out of the wall as Ty steps up to reass the few patrons-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry folks, bar's still open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice like this.   Kind of romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imonna have to go out back, wiggle some things around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be wigglin nothin round less I'm there to see it. Maceo rolls his eyes as he passes Ty on the way out with FLASHLIGHT. He freezes in his tracks as the FLASHLIGHT BE hits a FIGURE standing in the doorway- It is SHERIFF HIRAM PUGH, large and in charge.    Pugh st into the club as if he owns it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evenin, folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evenin, Sheriff. Sheriff Pugh looks around the near-empty club-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your lights gone out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know but that be a vilation of somethin or other. Ty has played this game before, trying to hold his ground without pissing off the white man with the badge-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just about to close up here. Pugh sniffs the air-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife been cookin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not tonight.   Went to the revival tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) I stood by there a while. Them nigras was singin up a storm. Ty doesn't respond. Sheriff Pugh stops right next to Stokely, giving him a dead-pan stare as he speaks. Stokel won't meet his eyes-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just come out here to look in on Toussaint- had that shooting two nights ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lot's of fighting in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is that. But me and Old Toussaint got us a greement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERIFF PUGH(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get these field hands suckin down that whiskey, hop em all up with music, there's gonna be some razors drawn. He only call me if it's a fatality. MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never been a killin in here.   Them youngbloods know better- SHERIFF PUGH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -than to mess with Tyrone Purvis. He turns his attention to Tyrone- SHERIFF PUGH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got quite the reputation round here, Tyrone. Say you put some poor black boy in the grave. It gets very quiet, the HISS of the KEROSENE LANTERN grow tense and insistent. China Doll looks from Sheriff Pugh to Ty's face, searchin for a flicker of evidence. Ty stays deadpan- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just people talkin. The Sheriff steps to put his face very close to Ty's, an of menace in his voice when he speaks softly- SHERIFF PUGH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember that this is my county, Tyrone. What goes on goes on cause I let it. Don't want to get too big for your britches out here. Ty holds Pugh's eyes for an agonizingly long moment, then sheriff turns and heads for the door- SHERIFF PUGH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You folks have a pleasant evening, now. They all wait for him to clear the door before they exhal STOKELY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nigger aint shit in this world. Maceo snatches the whiskey bottle from Stokely-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speakin for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't have this club, Tyrone, what you think you be? We TIGHTEN on Ty's face.   He has been thinking about thi very thing-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't be nothin. And if that aint true then grits aint groceries. A long TRAIN WHISTLE echoes outside-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha Mae pauses as she climbs the FRONT PORCH of her tw story wooden HOUSE, the nicest in the neighborhood, liste to the TRAIN WHISTLE with a troubled look on her face. Sl waits for her with the door open-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a terrible noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the northbound from Talledega. Sounds like it always does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a soul bein carried away from this life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in, darlin.     You catch your death out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the TRAIN WHISTLE again as the WHEELS ROLL and th TRAIN strobes past us, picking up speed as it pulls out f the yard- When it clears we see a LONE FIGURE standing across the tracks. He steps forward and catches a bit of light--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SONNY BLAKE, 20's, rumpled from hard travelling.   He car a GUITAR CASE and something bulky in a SACK- SHACK THOMAS, an older man in a PULLMAN PORTER'S UNIFORM stands under the moth-addled light on the tiny STATION PLATFORM, watching Sonny- SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky the high-sheriff aint here to see you crawl outta that boxcar. SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He come round here much? SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only when he's bored. Sonny reaches Shack at the platform- SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You working that train? SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kansas City to New Orleans. SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you get off here for? SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I growed up here. Still got people. How bout you? SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Got tired of sleepin in a boxcar. Listen, is there a place to- SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points) Switchman's shed, right over there, has got a cot. Don't mind the rats none, less you got food on you- and I can see you and a good meal has been strangers for some time. Sonny looks at the shed, unenthusiastic- SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get into town tomorrow an need somethin, tell em Shack Thomas sent you. They know who you talkin about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Hey, what's the name of this town? Shack points to the SIGN hanging down from the lip of the platform roof-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign reads-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name like that, must be a good place for musicians.

dialogues.speaker: PLATFORM
dialogues.text: Shack laughs as he heads away-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only night I ever spent in jail was a town called Liberty. Sun comes up, you'll see where you landed. And you best be out of that shed by first light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few wet, crumpled BILLS and dirty COINS are spread out the bartop-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a weekday night-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still operating by LANTERN LIGHT, Ty and Maceo look at th night's dismal take, as China Doll lays chairs on top of tables-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe the chicken man, I owe the ice man, I owe the liquor man-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Least you don't owe the electric company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates the dark room)    Yeah, that's a big relief. MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried)    You thinkin bout closing down? Ty frowns, reaches under the counter and brings up a POST He spreads it out on the counter top. It reads- SPECIAL ATTRACTION

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Orleans Singing Sensation `GUITAR' SAM TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you think? MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biggest act in New Orleans, got him a hit on the radio- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's playing here Saturday night. Figured I'd wait till Bertha Mae was gone to put this up. Ty turns to look for the right spot to fix the poster- MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here?   You mean like in this room here? TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the Tomcat Club in Texarkana? MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Jim Jamison's place- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just went out of business. MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And since Sam is giggin his way over to Tulsa, that means he got the date open-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you aint never had a guitar pl- Ty gives Maceo a warning look, which China Doll notes-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having one now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you gonna pay the man with? Ty glances at China Doll, uneasy-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just worry about gettin these hung up everywhere in the county tomorrow. Payday come Saturday, he gonna draw alla them cotton pickers and soldiers boys in here, get us back in the black. Ty looks around at the empty club-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gonna take me down, it won't be without a fight. Maceo holds the poster up to the lamplight, warming to th idea-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guitar Sam at the Honeydripper. Man, this joint is going to jump!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUNRISE. An OLD MAN in coveralls leads a MULE along the s of the road. A TRUCK carrying two dozen PICKERS in its open bed approa

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK
dialogues.text: One of the pickers, DEX, turns to look back at the man an mule-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aint seen no mule in a long time. The other pickers, men and women, don't look interested o even fully awake yet-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew this was Alabama, but that's the Stone Ages, man. One of the other men, HAM, looks him over. Dex is little combative and has a nasty-looking SCAR on his face. Ham i big and morose, with a deep, grumpy voice- HAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you from, boy? DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Memphis. HAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down on you vacation? A few snickers- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got in a piece of trouble up there with the white folks, need to bide my time for a spell. JUNEBUG, a local man with a nervous air, jumps in- JUNEBUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bide any time in these fields, bossman gonna fire your ass for takin up space. DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aint no worry bout that.   I'm a cotton-pickin fool. HAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a fool, all right. More snickers and the truck stops at the side of a COTTON FIELD. Somebody lets the tailgate down and they begin to climb off- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where you from, Brother Bear? HAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missippi. DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then this a real step up for you. Folks round here has discovered fire and whatnot-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That trouble you in have anything to do with runnin your mouth? The pickers unroll the sacks they pick up from the pile that's been left and begin to spread out at the base of t unpicked rows- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had to do with somebody get on my nerves and I had to deal with him. HAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must of been somebody kind of puny. Dex turns to face the much larger Ham- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I recall he just about your size. The two men stare at each other for a long moment. Way to early to fight. Dex breaks eye contact and moves toward a row- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this place we at? JUNEBUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearest town is Harmony.    This Mr. Silas Tugwell's place. He nods toward Dex's row- JUNEBUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get pickin. DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cotton aint goin nowhere. JUNEBUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More you get first thing when the dew still on it, the more it weighs when it tip that scale. Dex's gaze falls upon a tall, strong-looking young woman starting down the row next to his- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live here too? She gives him a weary look-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head)   You got my sympathies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WIDE SHOT of the TRACKS that cut the town in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny stands on the tracks just as the SUN RISES, ponderi which side of the tracks is for white people, which for t colored. He hears GUITAR MUSIC to one side, steps cautiously towar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny wanders down the street lugging his sack and case, moving toward the sound of a SLIDE GUITAR being played expertly- An irate-looking WHITE LADY glares at Sonny as she picks the milk bottles from her stoop, steps inside and slams t door. Sonny moves ahead, uneasy- We TIGHTEN on his face as he stops to listen, the MUSIC ECHOING, seeming to come from here, then from there, then suddenly from right behind him- He turns- POSSUM, blind, with his chair tilted back against the not open GENERAL STORE, PLAYS expertly on a beat-up old GUITA Sonny lays his case down to listen for a moment, watching man's fingers- Possum gets a whiff of him.     He keeps playing as he sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody slept in the railroad yard. Sonny watches the blind man's fingers move on the strings

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yall can play that thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been doin it near forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) Listen, which side of the tracks am I- POSSUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wrong side for you. SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you doing here then? POSSUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White folks look right through me. How much mischief an old blind spook like me gonna get up to anyhow? Sonny surveys the street- SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where our people go for music around here? POSSUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a couple places just a little bit out of town. At the crossroads. SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long walk? POSSUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You in a hurry? Possum finishes his song- SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is that box you playin, Pops? POSSUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Second one that ever was- an the devil's got the first. How bout yours? Possum gently nudges Sonny's case with his toe.   Sonny i surprised at the blind man's perception- SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brand new.     Made it myself. POSSUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whistles)     Made it hisself-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. So these clubs-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Toussaint, owns the Ace of Spades, don't feature live music. And Pinetop Purvis, owns the Honeydripper Lounge? He don't care bout no guitar. Won't have one under his roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't make sense. Possum scratches his head-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah- when a musician put his hand to murder, nine times outa ten it's a drummer done it. But Pinetop a piano man-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He killed somebody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the story.    Might be true, and it might not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty is tacking one of the Guitar Sam POSTERS on the front the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you meet the man, you damn well don't be askin him about it. A CRACKLE and a curse from the side of the roadhouse-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! Ty looks up-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you used to work for the power company.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE OF ROADHOUSE, MACEO
dialogues.text: Maceo wrestles with the jury-rigged WIRES that run out fr the battered, rusting POWER BOX- MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drove a supply truck. TY (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guitar Sam aint gonna play by no candlelight. MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffs)    I smell bacon. TY (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must of burnt your porky ass with that lectricity. CHINA DOLL (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast ready!

dialogues.speaker: FRONT OF ROADHOUSE
dialogues.text: China Doll has stepped out from the club- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your mama? CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already over to the Mayor's. She told me to come here and make sure you eat something fore you start runnin around. Maceo comes around from the side- MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a sweet woman you got. CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got one waitin for you if you want her. Maceo makes a face-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Nadine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step into the club. Plates of bacon, eggs and biscui sit on one of the tables-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing) Come in here every night makin them cow-eyes at you- Ty and Maceo sit-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seems like the kind could smother a man-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes all her own clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Darlin, that's not the kind of thing a man cares about from a woman. The LIGHTS that went out last night suddenly FLICKER ON-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I fixed it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't do no such thing. It just decided to come back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like it decided to switch off last night. You not even in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Nadine makes some good money too, sewing for people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That woman scares me. Last ole boy that give her a tumble, Nappy Carpenter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MACEO(cont'd) She cook for him, fixed him up all kinds of nice new clothes, kept him in gin and poker chips-

dialogues.speaker: CHINA DOLL
dialogues.text: Don't see no problem with that.

dialogues.speaker: MACEO
dialogues.text: Well, come four, five months, a man starts to- sorry, China Doll, but this just the way it is- a man gots needs.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Nadine look like she can take care of those, too-

dialogues.speaker: MACEO
dialogues.text: You eat chicken every morning, noon and night for five months, you get a taste for some different kind of meat, right? (looks to China Doll) Maybe I shouldn't be-

dialogues.speaker: CHINA DOLL
dialogues.text: Aint gonna tell me something I haven't heard worse.

dialogues.speaker: MACEO
dialogues.text: Well, Nappy goes out and has him a- a porkchop or two, let's say- and he comes back from Toussaint's one night feeling no pain, smelling like- like porkchops- the way a man will- and he falls out on Nadine's couch and commences to snore. Wake up the next mornin, finds she had took all his clothes off without him knowin it-

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Man was dog drunk-

dialogues.speaker: MACEO
dialogues.text: Miss Nadine come in with a skillet in her hand, hot grits bubbling in it, says "Baby, I got your breakfast." "Not this morning, Nadine," he says, sittin up, "don't think I could eat a thing." "Well then," she says, "we can't let this go to waste, can we?" and she dump that whole hot bubblin mess right in the man's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wincing)    Owwww! MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she got busy with that hot iron on his head. Screams didn't bring the neighbors in, she would of killed that man. They are all quiet for a moment, contemplating- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to admit it, though- woman is an artist with that Singer machine. SONNY (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scuse me? They turn to see Sonny standing in the doorway- SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one of you is Mr. Pinetop? Ty's eyes fix on Sonny's face for a moment- something familiar there- then go down to the guitar case at his fe TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We aint hirin. SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can play anything- Ty indicates the Guitar Sam POSTER hanging behind the bar TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already got me a professional. Sonny looks a little shaky- SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guitar Sam really coming all the way out here? TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That so surprising? SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no-- uhm, Mr. Shack Thomas said that if I was to- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Shack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We uh- we travelled together- Ty gives him a once-over- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the last time you ate solid food, young man? Sonny has to think- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to China Doll) Take him back and fix him somethin, China Doll. Standin there all hungry-eyed, puts me off my breakfast. SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's real kind of you- Sonny pulls his hat off as he follows China Doll, who is suddenly quiet and self-conscious, back to the kitchen- MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must of come in on the northbound last night. TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look like he got cooties, too. Straw in them boxcars is full of em. MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never cared to travel that way. Ty grows somber, reminiscing- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was out there ridin them rails between the wars. Seem like half the country headin west rolled past the other half comin back east. (musing) Every one of us scrapin for the next meal- COOL BREEZE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the place. They turn to see COOL BREEZE, a hard-looking, sharply-dre character, leading the prosperous looking MR. SIMMONS int the club as if they aren't there-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yall can tear things down, put things up- got a lot of potential. MR. SIMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks bigger in here than it does from the outside. TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I help you gentlemen? COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just showing the man gonna run this place what he's got. Ty stands- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my place. A frozen moment.    Then Maceo stands as well, backing up friend. Cool Breeze puts one foot up on the chair next to Ty, lic finger and dabs at his shoeshine with it- COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the piano player, right? TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Tyrone- call me Pinetop Purvis. COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinetop Purvis who owes two hundred dollars to Lucky Hardaway up in Little Rock- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna get his- COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinetop who missed last month's rent- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After this weekend- COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After this weekend you gonna be the same raggedy-ass piano player can't pay his debts off and Mr. Simmons here gonna be the new proprietor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky give me two weeks- COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky got a better offer. He nods toward Mr. Simmons- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't do that. Cool Breeze takes his foot down and gets up in Ty's face. lets his jacket fall open so the butt of his .44 PISTOL i visible- COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think so? MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to defuse) What if we got our payment for him Monday? Cool Breeze doesn't take his eyes off Ty's- COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saturday night. MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can do that- COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just a taste- the whole two hundred. TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I throw in a twenny-five cent tip for his messenger boy. COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be here. TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meantime, we not open yet. Which means yall are trespassin. Cool Breeze grins, still locking eyeballs with Ty- COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seen enough, Mr. Simmons? MR. SIMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool Breeze breaks eye contact, strolls out, followed by Simmons- COOL BREEZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, somebody could make something out of this place. Wouldn't take much work at all. Ty and Maceo wait till the men are gone before they speak TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cleared over two hundred that one weekend- MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple years back- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we didn't have no Louisiana guitar wizard playin neither. MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they say he draws em like flies. TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they say. An awkward pause.   Both men are shaken.   Ty sits back d think- MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say first thing he does is go to the man that owns the joint, sticks out his hand and wants that cash money put in it. TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already sent fifty to his manager. MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you payin him all out? TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another hundred. MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd have to clear three hundred- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure we charge folks two dollars to get in, then drinks-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) What I'm sayin is, less he sees the green up front the man won't get off the train. A TRUCK HORN honks outside-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that now? Ty, mind working, looks desperate as Maceo exits to see w honking-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A battered TRUCK sits in front of the club. ZEKE, a tacit white man, and his black loader step out as Maceo approac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out) Bout time you fellas run by. We just about dry here. The loader lets down the tailgate to reveal CASES OF BEER LIQUOR. He begins to pull them out and pile them on the ground-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boss in? Maceo shouts back into the club-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrone!   Whiskey wagon come by! Ty steps out of the club carrying one of the Guitar Sam posters-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all a day late. Ty nods at the Ace of Spades club across the way-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Man Toussaint gonna chew you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toussaint went over to another supplier upstate. We just got you, then we headin down to the army base, officers' club needs servicin. This fifty-six dollars-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weak grin) My credit no good anymore? Zeke only has to look at the loader, who starts to put th cases back onto the truck- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoah, whoah- what's your hurry? ZEKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody that's right in his head sell liquor on credit. Specially not to no darktown roadhouse. TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well this is like a special case, see- we got the harvest coming in, soldiers at the base gonna be let out on leave- Saturday night. Aint enough hootch in this truck to satisfy what we gonna sell- ZEKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pay as you go.   That's bidness. Zeke walks toward the cab of the truck, Ty following him, desperate, waving the poster- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can come by Monday, get paid and take back every damn drop I aint sold! We got Guitar Sam lined up, you know what that means?! Zeke steps in and slams the door, the loader doing the sa on the other side of him- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay you extra- penny a bottle on the beer and a nickel on the whiskey! The truck engine coughs- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate) What if I throw in five dollars up front, just for you fellas- ? Zeke pulls away-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man, everybody give credit, that's the American way! But the truck is gone down the road.   Maceo comes up bes Ty, watching forlornly- MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we could buy some busthead from Willie Pettigrew. TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that sheriff sniffin around every night? Land my black ass in jail for good. Another TRUCK pulls around the bend from the opposite direction- MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what we gonna do? The new truck slows to a stop by them.    The DRIVER poke head out- DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a liquor delivery for a Mr. Lucien Toussaint? MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be me. Maceo bites his tongue.   Ty plays it through- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust they got my check all right? DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't spose I'd be here if they didn't. Ty glances over to the Ace of Spades, then points behind Honeydripper- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull it around to the back- we'll help you unload.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver nods and wheels the truck past them.   Maceo's smile fades and he looks to Ty-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, this better be some Saturday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little kitchen built onto the back of the bar. Sonny si wolfing down eggs and toast as China Doll watches him fro the stove-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arkansas.    How bout you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come here just after Mama met my step-daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much happenin, little town like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) They started up the training base again-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been in the Army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shoot people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fixed radios.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say this new war gonna be a short one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might be, might not.    I was to Japan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What's the people like there? SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small. CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds a hand up) Bout that high. And they speak Japanese. CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been to California? SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods)   Los Angeles. CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where they make the movies. SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to the movies? CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been once. He sits back and looks her over- SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine-looking girl like you, ought to been all kinds of places. CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to em. First I'm going to beauty school when Mama saves up the money and then I have a portable skill- SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like playin music. CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My step-Daddy says that aint a skill- TY (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -it's an affliction. Ty sticks his head in, Maceo behind him with a case of li in his arms-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, China Doll. Got some bidness in town you gonna help me with. Ty gives Sonny a distrustful look-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, young man, want to point yourself west down that highway. Bout three miles you see a mess of people working in the fields- it's harvest time. If you can stoop and pull, they got a job for you. He steps out the back door-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And wash up them dishes before you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah is washing breakfast dishes, SINGING a gospel son she works-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see four and twenty elders Down on their knees I see four and twenty elders Down on their knees Well they all turn together Standing to greet the rising sun I see four and twenty elders Down on their knees AMANDA WINSHIP, the mayor's pretty, high-strung wife, ent and hovers uneasily-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your biscuits were wonderful this morning, Delilah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, they always are.   I don't know how you do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just cook em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I married Floyd I swear I couldn't even boil water. Might be why he insisted I needed help around the house. He used to come to the dinner table with a sense of dread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody can learn to cook. Just have to put your mind to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you could show me some of your secrets some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No secrets to it. Imonna fix some ham with yams and greens today, you want to learn how. Amanda thinks about it, smiling all the while, sighs-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe some other day. Delilah isn't surprised by the response-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just say the word, Miss Amanda, I have you cookin in no time. Amanda nods, uncomfortable but not leaving.   She can't exactly offer to help with the dishes-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't know what I'd do without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty, Maceo and China Doll approach the general store.    A COUPLE enter from the front-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I need is for you to go get friendly with Luther, then I just happen in-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't just ask Mr. Skinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Skinner don't want nothin from colored folks but they buy his goods and shine his shoes. You go on ahead, now- Maceo and China Doll cut around toward the back of the st We TIGHTEN on Ty as he unrolls the posters he carries, lo across the street for another likely place to hang one- POSSUM (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was early Friday evenin Hounds began to bark Ty turns-   how did Possum get there, chair and all? POSSUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stackolee an Billy Lyons Was squabblin In the dark Ty frowns at the lyrics- POSSUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stackolee said To Billy Lyons "What you think bout that? First you takes all my money Then you spits in My Stetson hat." TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate that damn song. Possum keeps playing but stops singing- POSSUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you keepin, Tyrone? TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wary) Just tryin to hold it together. POSSUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got your beautiful young daughter with you this mornin- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you be studyin her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard you gone put on a guitar man out your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins)   Oh- the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well this time the breeze know what it's blowin about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better be careful, Tyrone. You know what them guitar players are like. Ty glares at Possum-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful yourself. Ty stalks away around toward the back of the store.   Pos grins and sings again-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he shot him Three times in the shoulder Three times in the side That was the last time he shot him Cause Poor Billy Up and died

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quartet of WORKMEN and DELIVERYMEN lounge on piled up shipping crates as Shack Thomas stands addressing them-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The time is ripe and the bill is past due. Roosevelt would of done it already, only he died and they don't listen to Miss Eleanor no more. But Mr. Truman startin to bend, specially now that we got a war heatin up. As Brother Randolph says-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it comes-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shack looks to see Ty joining the others- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -the gospel accordin to A. Phillip Randolph. SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased)    Tyrone! How you doing, man? TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got my nose above the waterline. SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here's my baby- how's your mama doing, China Doll? He gives China Doll a hug and kiss- CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's doin fine, Uncle Shack. SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tellin the boys here how Brother Randolph pushin through this deal where our boys gonna be a full part of services- already got the Navy and the Air Force, and the Army is- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I carried a rifle in the Great War, Shack. Boys get in the middle of this Korea mess they aint gonna thank you for your efforts. SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want our due in this country, we got to go whole hog- TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black folks shooting yellow folks to keep the white folks happy? SHACK THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to move on from that kind of thinkin. Ty starts in through the back entrance of the store-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go ahead and move right on, Shack. Then come back and tell the rest of us how it is. He steps in.   Shack turns to China Doll-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a hard-headed man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUTHER, the head clerk, arranges boxes on the back wall a shoots a nervous look up front-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have to ask Mr. Skinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you would. While you at it, remind him how one of the reasons colored folks come in here is to get the lowdown on what's happening in-- Luther brightens as China Doll steps in-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: China Doll! Luther is clearly smitten-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna let us put these posters up, aint you Luther?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh-- I don't think that be any problem at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming a smile) That's awful nice of you, Luther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lookin special today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's sweet of you to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maceo, go on with the man and he show you where you can put em up. Come on, darlin, we got more stops to make- China Doll spreads a parting bit of sunshine-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you, Luther. Luther smiles and waves as Maceo hooks his arm and pulls back into the store-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty and China Doll hurry down the tracks and cross to the black side of town-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that boy eatin out of your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luther's the only one didn't pull my hair when he sit behind me at Sunday school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I hope you got a little that sugar left, cause we got to spread some on Miss Bertha Mae Spivey-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gone ask her to come sing again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imonna ask her for money. Word is she got a whole pile of it squirreled away. China Doll stops, breathing heavily, bends to put her han on her knees-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, girl, we in a rush here-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to rest. Ty softens, walks back to stand beside her-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, baby.   You catch your breath. China Doll smiles weakly-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So- why Miss Spivey gonna give you money, you don't let her sing at the club any more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna make her a partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Partner in what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the Honeydripper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all you ever say it's just a hole you pour good money into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't matter.     Imonna make her a proprietor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `tress'.   Like waiter and waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proprietress. She got to like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the GUITAR SAM POSTERS appears in the front window Maceo tapes it up- A trio on teenage girls stop to look at it as they pass (Possum is nowhere to be seen)- Maceo steps out to join them, eager to close the deal-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely ladies out to make a purchase-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That the same Guitar Sam is on the radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine lookin man. Real lady killer from what I hear. Got that New Orleans style to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to have a picture up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we'll be gettin some of those when he comes in on the train. The main thing is, the man is electrified- and you know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Formerly a fairly grand house, Bertha Mae's hasn't been painted for awhile and the yard could use some work. Ty coaches China Doll as they climb the stairs-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We make like we just come by to see how she's keepin, and then I'll kind of mention how I been thinking of bringing her on as a partner-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left the door open. China Doll pushes the front door all the way open. We can hear Bertha Mae's VOICE singing on a scratchy old RECORD. China Doll peeks in to see-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Slick, sitting at the bottom of the STAIRS that lead to second floor, looking lost and bewildered-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty frowns.    He was all geared up for the siege-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she gonna be back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just gone.   Woke up beside her and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't go on, tears forming in his eyes.       China Do trade a look-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start on the RECORD PLAYER, needle down on the spinnin song, then RACK to see Bertha Mae, laying DEAD in her bed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We RACK again as Ty and China Doll step in. Slick appears the doorway behind them. He's been drinking-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: China Doll, you go find your Mama. She know how to fix up the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People make jokes and all, but I been with that woman fourteen years. That's a good part of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And stop by Beauchamp's and tell em they got a customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gimme the only home I ever had. He looks at them, devastated-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm gonna do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny walking along. He has left his guitar and sack back the club. He slows, seeing-

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF'S CAR
dialogues.text: The SHERIFF'S CAR is sitting at the side of the road, a COUNTRY SONG playing on the radio-

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: He decides to brave it, walks ahead with his eyes fixed straight ahead. We he gets even with the car we see Sheri Pugh sitting in the driver's seat, watching him-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a hurry, boy? Sonny stops, looks to the Sheriff-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your hat off. Sonny takes his hat off. He meets the Sheriff's eyes, try to strike a balance between defiant and submissive-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you headed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookin for work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stranger wanderin around, no job- that would make you a vagrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm lookin-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a job for you.   Get in the back. Sonny doesn't even think about running away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black PRISON LABORERS pick cotton, watched over by an arm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can always use another hand. We SHIFT to see GATLIN, a white planter who chews and spi tobacco, looking Sonny over as Sheriff Pugh stands by-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caught this young fella in flagrant violation of the statutes. Gawkery with intent to mope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he gonna run me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three dollars a day plus you feed im lunch. Now the sentence- that depends on how long you gonna need the help. Sonny decides to speak up-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get any trial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you do, boy. And a speedy one, too. (points) Meet Judge Gatlin. Gatlin spits-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grab a sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maceo nails a Guitar Sam POSTER to a tree, looks over his handiwork. An ARMY PLATOON trudges into the crossroads, sweat-soaked footsore- Maceo watches, pleased, as the black soldiers check the poster out as they pass-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saturday night, fellas! Every fine- looking colored woman in the county gonna be there- don't want to miss it! A white LIEUTENANT passes, giving Maceo a dark look.   Ma salutes-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon, sir.   Nice lookin bunch of soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah sits at the dining room table with a sandwich she made herself. We hear PERRY COMO on a RECORD somewhere in the house. She hasn't gotten two bites down before Amanda wanders in, crossing to the liquor cabinet-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear, I believe it's about that time- She pulls out a DECANTER OF WINE-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you care to join me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you. Amanda pours herself a glass of wine-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you won't join me, you don't partake. That was thoughtless of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't take spirits and- what else? In your church? DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sort of between churches right now. I been thinking about changing over to the Holiness, but I- I haven't been sanctified yet. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah- DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's been a minister in this week- AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tent out by the fairgrounds. Delilah nods.   Amanda takes a drink- AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church I grew up in- we were Pentacostals- they wouldn't have anything but the human voice inside the church. And dancing- any kind of dancing, music, card playing-- well, it was very strict. They took up serpents. DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard of that. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell Floyd these stories and he's horrified. They've always been Methodists, Floyd's family. DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're good people too. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I married Floyd-- oh, it was quite a scandal among my relatives. As if I'd taken up with somebody in a cult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can be a trial, married folks differ in their religion. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your husband is a--- ? DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unaffiliated. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unaffiliated. I see.    He has his-- social club- DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Honeydripper. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a colorful name. DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must devote a great deal of his energy to it. DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just him and Maceo Green runs it, and then I go over and cook some when I get off here. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very- supportive of you. Considering the sort of- environment- DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) I been in those barrooms most of my life, Miss Amanda. Amanda realizes she has probed too deep, tries to back up AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see- DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a singer. I met Tyrone in the Paradise, down in Shreveport, China Doll was only two- Delilah considers, struggling to express who Ty is-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just kind of livin along, you know, drinking more than I ought-- then Tyrone. It was like a light come into my life. Delilah turns away, embarrassed to have revealed so much- DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People think things because he owns the Lounge, but they don't know him. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small minds are never in short supply. She crosses to look out a window- AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people in this town--- She catches herself, smiles- AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose they expected that Floyd, being from a prominent family- as prominent as is possible here in Harmony- would have chosen somebody more-- She fades away again, empties her glass- AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My people were very devout, but they weren't- financially successful. DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shame in that. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In school, if you didn't have shoes- She frowns at the memory, sighs- AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I forgot-- Amanda is up and out of the room.   Delilah frowns at the decanter, hurries to put it away. Amanda comes back in holding a DRESS for a young girl-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going through Emily's old things the other day, and I thought this would look just darling on your China Doll- Delilah examines the dress, which is clearly for a little girl- DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh- I don't think it would near fit her, Miss Amanda. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) How old is she now? DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) Oh my- I must have lost track somewhere along the line. Seventeen. She sits, still holding the dress, sneaks a look over to where the wine decanter was- DELILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a very nice thought. An awkward silence that Perry Como fills inadequately. A KNOCK at the back door, then China Doll steps in, not see Amanda right away- CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama?   They need you at- Delilah shifts her eyes to indicate- CHINA DOLL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, Miss Amanda.   I didn't know you was home. AMANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) China Doll! We were just recalling-    you used to play right here under this table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty sits staring, mind working overtime, staring at the de woman on the bed. He barely hears Slick talking to the undertaker behind him, busy filling out forms-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't any cash money I know of. She sold a good deal of the furniture, but there's still a nice- lookin sofa in the parlor. Only thing she cared for anymore was singin out to Pinetop's place- Ty looks at a large RING on Bertha's Mae's cold gray hand He touches it with a finger-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You welcome to look around the house- if there's anything your Missus might like-- long as it's not something personal to me and Bertha Mae- Ty draws his finger away from the ring as if burnt-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just- she got to go out in style, is what it is. The best you got, all the trimmins- lay it out for her. That's the way she lived it- that's the way she ought to leave it. Ty closes his eyes and buries his head in his hands-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blazing hot.    Cotton chaff in the air as the prison WOR bend to their   task, dragging long sacks behind them lik snakes. Even    the DEPUTIES are sweating rivulets as the stand by with   their SHOTGUNS in hand. Sonny is way behind the others, not dressed for the work, wincing as he pricks his fingers for the umpteenth time. NED, a little prisoner picking his way back in the opposi direction in a parallel row, takes pity on him-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all never done this job before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't say I have. NED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to set your pins out wide, bend over from the hip- Sonny widens his stance- NED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -and don't be bobbin up and down all the time. When you up, be up, but when you on the row, stay down. Sonny digs in and keeps low- NED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But most important, you got to get you a rhythm. Everything in this life got a rhythm to it- even pullin cotton off the plant. SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay it out for me. NED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not my rhythm- your rhythm. That's between you and the day and the work you got before you. Once you on it, don't let nothin and nobody push you off it. SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going so slow. NED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gettin paid by the pound or by the hour? SONNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gettin paid at all.   None of us are. Ned cackles- NED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I suggest you work that into your rhythm too. A DEPUTY calls out-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see more pickin and less talkin over there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gettin right on it, Boss! Ned picks his way behind Sonny. Sonny starts to rock slightly, looking for a rhythm of movement he can maintai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The free pickers sit on and around the truck that brought them, eating lunch. Dex watches the prison laborers acros the road as he SHUFFLES a battered DECK OF CARDS, sitting with a couple of the other men-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them boys fryin over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Judge Gatlin's gang- he work them people from can until can't, ever damn day, and when his fields is picked he bid em out to the neighbors. Harvest time comes round here, you sign up with somebody fast or you stay outa sight. Dex waves flies away from his face, spits-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ate a peck of dust today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take some water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only thing wash the dust out is whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Aint enough whiskey in this world wash out what I swallowed in my life. Dex riffles the cards-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we playin for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two bits a hand. JUNEBUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's kind of steep- Dex laughs and starts to deal a card at a time to the pla DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I member playin this game one night- Memphis is Boss Crump's town, folks is gamblin before they can walk- ten dollars a hand. I caught a winnin streak that cleaned out half the sportin men on Beale Street. Got up from that table, my money was as long as train smoke- JUNEBUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happen to it? Dex raises his voice so the woman he checked out in the morning can hear- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spent it all on fine-lookin women. He calls to where Ham stands in knee-high grass, a heavy stick in his hand, staring intently at the ground- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, Missippi- JUNEBUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name Hamilton. DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hambone!   You want in on this? He raises a matchstick in his fingers- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settle up on payday. HAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your deck of cards? DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if it is? HAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stay clear of it then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dex stops dealing to stare at Ham, insulted- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sinuatin? HAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just sayin I don't want to play. There is a sudden RUSTLING at Ham's feet and WHAP! he bri his stick down hard. He pulls up a RABBIT, dead, by its h legs- JUNEBUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like dinner. DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbit is a rodent. Man eat a rabbit, might's well eat a rat. Dex snorts, disgusted, then finishes dealing. He lays the top card face up and slaps down the rest of the deck- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters) Simple country nigger, fraid to sit down an lose his little handful of change-- JUNEBUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He awful big to mess with. DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't scare me none. I'm a steppin razor, man, I'm trouble on two legs. We hear a CAR APPROACHING, SLOWING DOWN- DEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your draw, Junebug. And don't be drippin sweat on my cards. MACEO (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, folks- They turn to see Maceo leaning out of the window of Ty's Ford, a Guitar Slim POSTER taped to the side of it- MACEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
